[**Take My Hand**]{.book-title}

[Dolen Perkins-Valdez]{.book-author}

[Read: December 2025]{.book-year}

[A book that taught me (once again) that fiction and narrative are more powerful tools to grasp the gravity of uncomfortable historic events and social facts. ]{.book-note}
:::

::: {.book-info}
[**Best Of Friends**]{.book-title}

[Kamila Shamsie]{.book-author}

[Read: December 2025]{.book-year}

[Girls everywhere are the same, and ones from the Indian subcontinent are particularly plucky. I enjoyed the stories of two friends in Pakistan, all the way from girlhood in Karachi to rich professional careers in London. ]{.book-note}
:::
:::

[**Americanah: A novel**]{.book-title}

[Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie]{.book-author}

[Read: October 2024]{.book-year}

[This book made everything simultaneously better by validating my observations about Americans, and worse by not redeeming them from my already unflattering impression.]{.book-note}
:::

[Read: 2024]{.book-year}

If you're unfamiliar with history China, Korea and Japan, you may not make the connections, but if you do, it will be cathartic and poetic, you'll love how beautifully the story addresses deep, shared wounds. ]{.book-note}
